results.title: Eclipse '73
results.creator_credit: Gilbert Dassonville and Service du film de Research Scientifique
results.brief_description: A report on the solar eclipse of June 30, 1973 seen from the ground and from a plane. The 1973 eclipse was monitored in Africa, south of the Sahara. Deals with the considerable means employed by the international scientific community while showing the mechanics of an eclipse and its value for basic research. At Atar in the heart of the Mauritanian desert together with other Soviet, Japanese, Dutch and Italian scientists, the French mission brought in more than 20 tons of equipment, and used the most advanced technological means. The use of a supersonic Concorde 001, especially equipped by aerospace for this flight enabled them for the first time to monitor an eclipse for 74 minutes.

results.title: The Echinoderms
results.creator_credit: Dennis Sawyer and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Intertidal Life of the North American Pacific Coast”.
A few species of the phylum Echinodermata found in the rich environment of the North American Pacific coast are shows. Four of the five classes are found in the inter-tidal region: Asteroidea, sea-stars; Ophiuroidea, brittle stars; Holothuriodea, sea cucumbers; and Echinoidea, sea-urchins. Uses micro-photogpraphy.

results.title: Eastern Europe: an introduction
results.brief_description: A geographic and historical survey of Poland, Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia, Bulgaria, Rumania, Hungary and Albania; the agriculture, industry and important cities of this area under communist domination. A variety of landforms and diverse cultural backgrounds contribute to a wide variation of human use and living standards.

results.title: East Germany: beyond the Wall
results.creator_credit: Palmer Williams, Edward Magruder Jones and Columbia Broadcasting System Television
results.brief_description: Life in East Germany. The influence of the Communist Party on home life, work, churches and schools. Includes interviews with a capitalistic businessman, a pastor, an official of Rostock University and Walter Ulbricht, Chairman of East Germany’s Council of State.

results.title: East Anglian holiday
results.creator_credit: Michael Clarke, Edgar H. Anstey, Ian Ferguson and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: Describes the beauty and historical associations of the East Anglia district of England. Mentions the open country of Norfolk as being a delight of gardeners and naturalists; and the lushness of Suffolk made famous by Constable. Includes shots of the “Broads”, home of sails, windmills and quiet waterways, Flatford and Horstead Mills and the old town of King’s Lynn. Narrated by Frank Duncan and Richard George.

results.title: Earthworms
results.brief_description: The earthworm is dissected and its muscular, nervous, digestive and reproductive systems are examined; the bisexual reproductive process is shown, and the emergence of a young earthworm completes the life cycle study. The importance of earthworms in aerating and enriching the soil is stressed.

results.title: Earthworm: anatomy and dissection
results.brief_description: Stresses correct laboratory techniques for dissection, showing a close look at the digestive, circulatory, excretory, nervous, and reproductive systems of the earthworm. Shows functioning of these systems by means of extreme close-up photography, photomicrography and diagrams.

results.title: Earthware
results.creator_credit: Donald Winkler, Richard Raxlen, Colin Low, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This short impressionistic film takes us to Nigeria, Japan, Mexico where craftsmen work clay to produce ritual vessels and everyday objects. Film without words.

results.title: Our changing earth. Part 1. The Earth's rocky crust
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Harvard Film Service, Harvard University
results.brief_description: Physiography is presented as a dynamic process: the forces which have shaped the earth as it is today are still at work changing it further. The part played by the water cycle in determining the physiography of the earth is emphasised, and the formation of igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic rocks is illustrated by models and by animated diagrams.
